detail.content: Art and Public Policy Open House: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content          < back        Art and Public Policy Open House  Event Date and Time: November 6, 2014 2:30 - 4pm Location: Dean's Conference Room 721 Bway, 12th fl New York, NY 10003 Want to learn more about the Undergraduate Minor in Art and Public Policy?      Curious about an MA in Arts Politics?      Interested in taking a spring course in our department?         The Department of Art and Public Policy, Tisch School of the Arts invites current NYU undergraduate and graduate students and other prospective MA students to find out more about the unique opportunities offered by the department. We engage students in critical and creative dialogue about art, society, and reshaping the landscape for careers in the arts and beyond. Many courses offered through the department are open to both undergraduate and graduate students, and the department offers a minor to undergraduates from across NYU.      Spring 2015 courses will include:      All School Seminar: The dilemma of the non-profit theater, Prof. Oskar Eustis (graduate students only)      Exit Strategies: Funding Your Work, Prof. Elizabeth Mikesell      Female Cultural Rebels, Prof. Karen Finley      Green World, Prof. Peter Terezakis      Language as Action: Narrating Change, Prof. Kathy Engel      Special Topics: Directed Research, Prof. Adonis Volanakis      The Cultural Imperative: Intersections in Cultural Equity, Cultural Arts & Public Policy, Dr. Marta Moreno Vega      Visit our open house to hear from faculty, alumni, and current students! The Cultural Imperative: Intersections Cultural Equity, : Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content          < back        The Cultural Imperative: Intersections Cultural Equity, Cultural Arts and Public Policy  IOART-UT.2100  4 Credits Instructor(s): M. Vega Please note this course takes place on location in Puerto Rico during NYU January Term, January 7-25, 2013.  The course will provide  students that opportunity to do a comparative analysis of the cultural policies  and practices of Puerto Rico, a commonwealth of the United States, and those of  the United States. Central to the analysis will be focused on issues of  Cultural Equity in public policy, distribution of resources, racial and  economic status of diverse communities.      Students will have direct  access to scholars, policymakers, community institution builders and cultural  activists focused on structuring policies, providing resources and generating  practices of cultural equity for the diverse racial and economic communities of  Puerto Rico. Given the diversity of  racial, ethnic and economic diversity of the United States students will have  the opportunity to focus and experience the root cultures of one of the major  Caribbean populations that have migrated to the United States. The course will provide a framework of  engaging in diverse cultural models, respecting and understanding the  historical legacy and contributions of Puerto Ricans on the island and the  United States, engage with artist and policymakers focused on traditional, popular  and contemporary cultural issues, public policy and cultural equity work,  skills that are necessary for working in  varied cultural environments.  Students who would like to be considered for this course must fill out the program application .  Note :   In addition to the tuition, this course has a nonrefundable program fee (TBA), which will cover housing and some meals.  Winter session tuition will be available in October. Please visit the NYU Bursar's website for details.       Office of Special Programs 721 Broadway, 12th Floor New York, NY 10003  Contact us! Program Curriculum: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Special Programs What Is Special Programs? Study Abroad Summer High School Summer in New York City Programs for Visiting Students Open Arts Minors Blog Events Newsletters Videos Admin & Faculty Alumni Contact Us  home > Special Programs        Program Curriculum  This course does not have a prerequisite. Puerto Rico: The Cultural Imperative: Intersections, Cultural Equity, Cultural Arts and Public Policy Undergraduate: IOART-UT.1100 Graduate: IOART-UT.2100 Instructor: Dr. Marta Moreno Vega 4 units The course will provide students with an opportunity to do a comparative analysis of the cultural policies and practices of Puerto Rico, a commonwealth of the United States, and those of the United States. Central to the analysis will be a focus on issues of Cultural Equity in public policy, distribution of resources, and racial and economic status of diverse communities. Students will have direct access to scholars, policymakers, community institution builders and cultural activists focused on structuring policies, providing resources and generating practices of cultural equity for the diverse racial and economic communities of Puerto Rico. Given the racial, ethnic and economic diversity of the United States, students will have the opportunity to focus and experience the root cultures of one of the major Caribbean populations that have migrated to the United States. The course will provide a framework for engaging in diverse cultural models and also respecting and understanding the historical legacy and contributions of Puerto Ricans on the island and the United States. In addition, it will also provide engagement with artists and policymakers focused on traditional, popular, and contemporary cultural issues as well as public policy and cultural equity work which are skills necessary for working in varied cultural environments. Note: In addition to the tuition, this course has a $625 nonrefundable program fee which will cover housing, course excursions, and some meals. Please visit the NYU Bursar's website for details.
